title: Sahak II of Cilicia
text:
Sahak II or Isaac II, last name Khabayan () (March 25, 1849 – October 8, 1939), was <a href="Catholicos%20of%20Cilicia">Catholicos of Cilicia</a> of the <a href="Armenian%20Apostolic%20Church">Armenian Apostolic Church</a> in 1902–1939.
Born in the village of Yeghiki in <a href="Harput">Kharpert</a>, he received his religious training in <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> and <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>. He was Catholicos of Cilicia during the tumultuous years of the <a href="Armenian%20genocide">Armenian genocide</a>, and was first exiled from the <a href="Episcopal%20see">see</a>'s seat in <a href="Kozan%2C%20Adana">Sis</a>, and then again after relocating to <a href="Adana">Adana</a>. From 1921 the Catholicos wandered the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> from place to place with no permanent home.
By 1929, aged 80 and weary, Catholicos Sahak appealed for help to the <a href="Near%20East">Near East</a> Relief organization, which had built several <a href="orphanage">orphanage</a>s for orphaned Armenian children fleeing the genocide. One of these orphanages was in the town of <a href="Antelias">Antelias</a> near <a href="Beirut">Beirut</a>, <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, which they leased to the Catholicos for one dollar a year. Sahak also sought to bring his dream for an Armenian <a href="theological%20seminary">theological seminary</a> to life at this site, since all <a href="seminaries">seminaries</a> under his jurisdiction had been closed or fallen apart after the genocide.
Due to his advanced age, Sahak II encouraged the election of a co-adjutor Catholicos to share his throne. <a href="Papken%20I%20Guleserian">Papken I Guleserian</a> reigned along with Sahak from 1931 until his death in 1936. Sahak II lived on another three years until his death at age 90.
